contextId.information: The author speaks of the Son as if he will inherit wealth and property from his Father. AT: "to possess all things" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: to be the heir of all things

contextId.information: This means Jesus. The author refers to him as the "firstborn" to emphasize the Son's importance and authority over everyone else. It does not imply that there was a time before Jesus existed or that God has other sons like Jesus. AT: "his honored Son, his only Son" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the firstborn

contextId.information: Christ's enemies are spoken of as if they will become an object on which a king rests his feet. This image represents defeat and dishonor for his enemies. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: until I make your enemies a stool for your feet

contextId.information: Receiving what God has promised believers is spoken of as if it were inheriting property and wealth from a family member. AT: "for those whom God will save" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: for those who will inherit salvation

contextId.information: Believing in God's word less and less is spoken of as if a boat were drifting away on the water from where it should be. AT: "so that we do not gradually stop believing it" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: so that we do not drift away

contextId.information: The author speaks of people being less important than angels as if the people are standing in a position that is lower than the angels' position. AT: "less important than the angels" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: a little lower than the angels

contextId.information: The author speaks of humans having control over everything as if they have stepped on everything with their feet. AT: "You have given them control over everything" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: You put everything in subjection under his feet

contextId.information: The experience of death is spoken of as if it were food that was tasted. AT: "has experienced death" or "has died" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: has tasted death

contextId.information: The gift of glory is spoken of here as if it were a place to which people could be brought. AT: "save many sons" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: bring many sons to glory

contextId.information: The author speaks of salvation as if it were a place where Jesus led them. This means Jesus is the person who acted first in order to save others. AT: "the one who saves other people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the leader of their salvation

contextId.information: This speaks about those who believe in Christ as if they were children. AT: "those who are like my children ... those who are like children to God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the children ... the children of God

contextId.information: The fear of death is spoken of as if it were slavery. Taking away someone's fear is spoken of as it were freeing that person from slavery. AT: "This was so he might free all people. For we lived like slaves because we were afraid of dying" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: This was so that he would free all those who through fear of death lived all their lives in slavery

contextId.information: Descendants of Abraham are spoken of as if they were his seed. AT: "the descendants of Abraham" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: seed of Abraham

contextId.information: Here "brothers" refer to fellow Christians, including both men and women. AT: "holy brothers and sisters" or "my holy fellow believers" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_gendernotations]])
contextId.quote: holy brothers

contextId.information: The Hebrew people to whom God revealed himself are spoken of as if they were a literal house. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:heb:03:01|3:2]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: in God's entire house

contextId.information: This speaks about God's people as if they were a literal house. AT: "who rules over God's people" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: in charge of God's house

contextId.information: This speaks of a manner of conducting one's life as if it were a way or a path. AT: "They do not understand how I wanted them to conduct their lives" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: They have not known my ways

contextId.information: Here this refers to fellow Christians including males and females. AT: "brothers and sisters" or "fellow believers" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_gendernotations]])
contextId.quote: brothers

contextId.information: The heart of a person is spoken of as if it were the entire person, who could abandon the right path to follow. AT: "and you stop obeying the living God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: a heart that turns away from the living God

contextId.information: The peace and security provided by God are spoken of as if they were rest that he can give, and as if they were a place to which people could go. AT: "they would not enter the place of rest" or "they would not experience his blessings of rest" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: they would not enter his rest

contextId.information: God's promise is spoken of as if it were a gift that God left behind when he visited the people. AT: "none of you fail to enter into God's rest, which he promised to us" or "God will allow you all to enter into his rest as he promised us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: none of you might seem to have failed to reach the promise left behind for you to enter God's rest

contextId.information: The peace and security provided by God are spoken of as if they were rest that he can give, and as if they were a place to which people could go. AT: "who will enter the place of rest" or "who will experience God's blessings of rest" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: who will enter that rest

contextId.information: The peace and security provided by God are spoken of as if they were rest that he can give, and as if they were a place to which people could go. AT: "They will never enter the place of rest" or "They will never experience my blessings of rest" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: They will never enter my rest

contextId.information: The author speaks of the world as if it were a building set on a foundation. AT: "at the beginning of the world" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: at the foundation of the world

contextId.information: Stubbornness is spoken of as if it were a heart that had been physically hardened. AT: "do not be stubborn." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:heb:03:07|3:7-8]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: do not harden your hearts

contextId.information: The peace and security provided by God are spoken of as if they were rest that Joshua could give. AT: "if Joshua had brought the Israelites to the place where God would give them rest" or "if the Israelites during the time of Joshua had experienced God's blessings of rest" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: if Joshua had given them rest

contextId.information: Eternal peace and security are spoken of as if they were the Sabbath day, the Jewish day of worship and rest from working. AT: "eternal rest" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Sabbath rest

contextId.information: The peace and security provided by God are spoken of as if they are a place to enter. AT: "the person who enters into God's place of rest" or "the person who experiences God's blessings of rest" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: he who enters into God's rest

contextId.information: Disobedience is spoken of as if it were a hole that a person could physically fall into by accident. This passage can be reworded so that the abstract noun "disobedience" is expressed as the verb "disobey." AT: "will disobey in the same way as they did" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: will fall into the kind of disobedience that they did

contextId.information: A two-edged sword can easily cut through a person's flesh. God's word is very effective in showing what is in a person's heart and thoughts. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: sharper than any two-edged sword

contextId.information: This continues speaking about God's word as if it were a sword. Here the sword is so sharp that it can cut through and divide parts of the human that are very difficult or even impossible to divide. This means that there is nothing inside of us that we can hide from God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: It pierces even to the division of soul from spirit, and joints from marrow

contextId.information: This speaks about all things as if they were a person standing bare, or a box that is open. AT: "everything is completely exposed" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: everything is bare and open

contextId.information: Belief and trust are spoken of as if they were objects that a person could grasp firmly. AT: "let us continue to believe confidently in him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: let us firmly hold to our beliefs

contextId.information: The high priest's own weakness is spoken of as if it were a force that surrounded him. AT: "is spiritually weak" or "is weak against sin" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: is surrounded with weakness

contextId.information: Honor is spoken of as if it were an object that a person could grasp in his hands. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: takes this honor

contextId.information: Death is spoken of as it if were place that Christ could be kept from being forced to enter, or as a place from which he could be rescued. Either meaning fits here. The UDB chooses the first meaning. If possible, translate so as to allow both interpretations. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: to save him from death

contextId.information: The ability to understand and obey is spoken of as if it were the ability to listen.  And the ability to listen is spoken of as if it were a metal tool that becomes dull with use. AT: "you have trouble understanding it" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: you have become dull in hearing

contextId.information: Teaching about God that is easy to understand is spoken of as if it were milk, the only food that infants can take. AT: "You have become like babies and can drink only milk" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: You need milk

contextId.information: This speaks of a believer who can understand only the simple teachings of the gospel as if he were a literal baby. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: because he is still a baby

contextId.information: This speaks about the basic teachings as if they were the beginning of a journey and the mature teachings as if they were the end of a journey. AT: "let us stop only discussing what we first learned and start understanding more mature teachings as well" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: let us leave the beginning of the message of Christ and move forward to maturity

contextId.information: Sinful deeds are spoken of as if they belonged to the world of the dead. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: dead works

contextId.information: Basic teachings are spoken of as if they were a building whose construction begins by laying a foundation. AT: "nor the basic teachings ... eternal judgment" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: nor the foundation of teaching ... eternal judgment

contextId.information: Understanding is spoken of as if it were illumination. AT: "those who once understood the message about Christ" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: those who were once enlightened

contextId.information: The Holy Spirit, who comes to believers, is spoken of as if he were an object that people could share. AT: "who received the Holy Spirit" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: who were sharers of the Holy Spirit

contextId.information: When people turn away from God, it is as though they crucify Jesus again. AT: "it is like they crucify for themselves the very Son of God again" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: they crucify the Son of God for themselves again

contextId.information: This speaks of "curse" as if it were a place to which a person could draw near. AT: "is in danger of God cursing it"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: is near to a curse

contextId.information: Receiving what God has promised believers is spoken of as if it were inheriting property and wealth from a family member. AT: "receive what God promised them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: inherit the promises

contextId.information: The people to whom God has made promises are spoken of as if they were to inherit property and wealth from a family member. AT: "to those who would receive what he promised" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: to the heirs of the promise

contextId.information: Trust in God is spoken of as if faith were an object that could be presented to a person and that person could hold on to it. AT: "will continue to trust in God just has he encouraged us to do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: will have a strong encouragement to hold firmly to the confidence that has been placed before us

contextId.information: Just as an anchor keeps a boat from drifting in the water, Jesus keeps us secure in God's presence. AT: "that causes us to live securely in God's presence" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: as a secure and reliable anchor of our souls

contextId.information: This was the most holy place in the temple. It was thought to be the place where God was most intensely present among his people. In this passage, this place stands for heaven and God's throne room.  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the inner place

contextId.information: The fact that Jesus died and rose again, and that he is now with God the Father, indicate that we who believe in him will experience the same things. Jesus is spoken of here as if he were someone who runs ahead of us and that we are running after him. AT: "as one who goes before us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: as a forerunner for us

contextId.information: This is a way of saying that they were descendants of Abraham. AT: "they, too, are descendants of Abraham" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: they, too, have come from Abraham's body

contextId.information: The things that God promised to do for Abraham are spoken of as if they were objects that he could possess. AT: the one to whom God had spoken his promises" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the one who had the promises

contextId.information: It is never explicitly written in scripture that Melchizedek dies. The author of Hebrews speaks of this absence of information about Melchizedek's death in scripture as if it were a positive statement that he is still alive. This can be stated in active form. AT: "scripture shows that he lives on"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: is testified that he lives on

contextId.information: Confidence for the future is spoken of as if it were an object through which a person must go in order to approach God. AT: "God gave us a better reason to have confidence in him, because he makes it possible for us to come near to him" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: there is the introduction of a better confidence for the future through which we approach God

contextId.information: "and God has raised him up to the highest heavens." The author speaks of possessing more honor and power than anyone else as if it were position that is up above all things. AT: "and God has given him more honor and power than anyone else" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: and has become higher than the heavens

contextId.information: The writer speaks of a person's conscience as if it were an object that could be made better and better until it was without fault. A person's conscience is his knowledge of right and wrong. It is also his awareness of whether or not he has done wrong. If he knows he has done wrong, we say that he feels guilty. AT: "are not able to make the worshiper free from guilt"   (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: are not able to perfect the worshiper's conscience

contextId.information: God's presence in heaven is spoken of as if it were the most holy place, the innermost room in the tabernacle. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: most holy place

contextId.information: Here "cleanse" stands for the action of relieving our consciences from guilt for the sins we have committed. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: cleanse

contextId.information: Making something acceptable to God is spoken of as if it were cleansing that thing. This idea can be stated in active form. AT: "the priests use blood to cleanse almost everything" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: almost everything is cleansed with blood

contextId.information: This speaks about sin as if it were an object that a person could put away. AT: "to cause God to forgive sins by sacrificing himself" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: to put away sin by the sacrifice of himself

contextId.information: The act of making us innocent rather than guilty for our sins is spoken of as if our sins were physical objects that Christ could carry away from us. AT: "so that God would forgive the sins" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: to take away the sins

contextId.information: This speaks about the law as if it were a shadow. The author means the law was not the good things that God had promised. It only hinted at the good things that God was going to do. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the law is only a shadow of the good things to come

contextId.information: People's sins are spoken of as if they could be physically washed away. This can be stated in active form. AT: "if God had already forgiven their sins" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: if they had been cleansed

contextId.information: Sins are spoken of as if they were objects that animal blood could sweep away as it flowed. AT: "For it is impossible for the blood of bulls and goats to cause God to forgive sins" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: For it is impossible for the blood of bulls and goats to take away sins

contextId.information: Starting the second way of atoning for sins is spoken of as establishing that practice. AT: "in order to atone for sins the second way" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: in order to establish the second practice

contextId.information: This speaks of "sins" as if they are an object that a person can take away. AT: "can never cause God to forgive sins" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: can never take away sins

contextId.information: The humiliation of Christ's enemies is spoken of as if they were made a place for him to rest his feet. This can be stated in active form. AT: "until God humiliates Christ's enemies and they become like a stool for his feet" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: until his enemies are made a stool for his feet

contextId.information: Here this means all believers in Christ whether male or female. AT: "brothers and sisters" or "fellow believers" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_gendernotations]])
contextId.quote: brothers

contextId.information: The curtain in the earthly temple represents the separation between people and God's true presence. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: through the curtain

contextId.information: This speaks about God's people as if they were a literal house. AT: "all the people of God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the house of God

contextId.information: Here "hearts" stands for the conscience, the awareness of right and wrong. Being made clean stands for being forgiven and being given the status of righteousness. Hearts are spoken of as if they could be cleansed by blood. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: hearts sprinkled clean

contextId.information: Here a set of beliefs that a person confesses is spoken of as if it were an object that a person could hold in his hand. The phrase "hold tightly" means "to continue." AT: "continue telling people that we are confident because we believe that God will do what he has promised to do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: hold tightly to the confession of our confident expectation

contextId.information: A future time is spoken of as if it were an object coming closer to the speaker. Here "the day" refers to when Jesus will return. AT: "as you know that Christ will return soon" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: as you see the day coming closer

contextId.information: Knowledge of the truth is spoken of as if it were an object that could be given by one person to another. AT: "after we have learned the truth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: after we have received the knowledge of the truth

contextId.information: Learning the truth is spoken of as if God shined a light on the person. This can be stated in active form. AT: "after you learned the truth about Christ" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: after you were enlightened

contextId.information: God's eternal blessings are spoken of as a "possession." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: a better and everlasting possession

contextId.information: Rejecting a promise is spoken of as if it were throwing away something worthless or useless. AT: "do not stop confidently trusting in God, who will reward you greatly" or "continue to trust completely in God, who will reward you greatly" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: do not throw away your confidence, which has a great reward

contextId.information: Losing courage and faith are spoken of as if it were turning back from following a path. And "destruction" is spoken of as if it were a destination. AT: "who stop trusting God, which will cause him to destroy us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: who turn back to destruction

contextId.information: Reading the scriptures and learning about Abel's faith is spoken of as if Abel himself were still speaking. AT: "we still learn from what Abel did" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Abel still speaks

contextId.information: Wanting to worship God and belong to his people is spoken of as if the person is literally coming to God. AT: "that anyone who wants to belong to God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: that anyone coming to God

contextId.information: Learning about God and making an effort to obey him is spoken of as if it were someone seeking to find another person. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: those who seek him

contextId.information: Noah is spoken of as if he were to inherit property and wealth from a family member. AT: "received from God the righteousness" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: became an heir of the righteousness

contextId.information: The land that God promised to give Abraham's descendants is spoken of as if it were an inheritance that Abraham was to receive. AT: "that God would give him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: that he was to receive as an inheritance

contextId.information: This speaks of promises as if they are objects that a person receives. AT: "without receiving what God had promised them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: without receiving the promises

contextId.information: Fully concentrating on achieving a goal is spoken of as if a person were staring at an object and refusing to look away. AT: "doing what he knew would earn him a reward in heaven" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: fixing his eyes on his reward

contextId.information: The writer speaks about the Old Testament believers as if they were a cloud that surrounded the present-day believers. This can be stated in active form. AT: "such a large cloud of witnesses surrounds us" or "there are so many examples of faithful people about whom we learn in the scriptures" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: we are surrounded by such a large cloud of witnesses

contextId.information: Here "weight" and "easily entangling sin" are spoken of as if a person could take them off himself and put them down. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: let us lay aside every weight and easily entangling sin

contextId.information: Attitudes or habits that keep believers from trusting and obeying God are spoken of as if they were loads that would make it difficult for a person to carry while running. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: every weight

contextId.information: Following Jesus is spoken of as if it were running a race. AT: "Let us continue obeying what God has commanded us, just like a runner keeps going until the race is over" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Let us patiently run the race that is placed before us

contextId.information: The joy that would belong to Jesus is spoken of as if God the Father had placed it before him to reach as a goal. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the joy that was placed before him

contextId.information: Those whom God does not discipline are spoken of as if they are sons born to a man and a woman who are not married each other. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: then you are illegitimate and not his sons

contextId.information: This metaphor speaks of "holiness" as if it were an object that can be shared among people. AT: "so that we may become holy as God is holy" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: so that we can share in his holiness

contextId.information: Righteousness, the quality of someone who obeys God, is spoken of as if it were fruit growing on a tree. Here the writer is saying that righteousness increases as a result of discipline. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: fruit of righteousness

contextId.information: In this metaphor of running a race, "lame" represents another person in the race who is hurt and wants to quit. This, in turn, represent the Christians themselves. AT: "whoever is weak and wants to quit will not sprain his ankle" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: what is lame will not be sprained

contextId.information: This can be stated in active form. AT: "instead become strong" or "instead God will heal him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: rather be healed

contextId.information: Here "Pursue" is spoken of as if it were something that a person must chase after. AT: "Try to live peacefully with everyone" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Pursue peace with everyone

contextId.information: Hateful or resentful attitudes are spoken of as if they were a plant bitter to the taste. AT: "that no one becomes like a bitter root, which when it grows causes trouble and harms many people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: that no root of bitterness grows up to cause trouble, so that many do not become polluted by it

contextId.information: The writer speaks of Mount Zion, the temple mount in Jerusalem, as if it were heaven itself, the residence of God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Mount Zion

contextId.information: This speaks of believers in Christ as if they were firstborn sons. This emphasizes their special place and privilege as God's people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the firstborn

contextId.information: Disobeying God is spoken of as if a person were turning and walking away from him. AT: "if we disobey the one who is warning" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: if we turn away from the one who is warning

contextId.information: Being persuaded by various teachings is spoken of as if a person were being carried away by a force. This can be stated in active form. AT: "Do not let others persuade you to believe their various strange teachings" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: Do not be carried away by various strange teachings

contextId.information: This can be stated in active form. AT: "we become stronger when we think of how God has been kind to us, but we do not become stronger by obeying rules about food" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: it is good that the heart should be strengthened by grace, not by foods that do not help those who walk by them

contextId.information: Living is spoken of as if it were walking. AT: "those who live by them" or "those who regulate their lives by them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: those who walk by them

contextId.information: Obeying Jesus is spoken of as if a person were leaving the camp to go out where Jesus is. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Let us therefore go to him outside the camp

contextId.information: Disgrace is spoken of as if it were an object that had to be carried in one's hands or on one's back. AT: "while allowing others to insult us just like people insulted him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: bearing his shame

contextId.information: Praise is spoken of as if it were a sacrifice of animals or incense. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: sacrifices of praise

contextId.information: Praise is spoken of as if it were fruit, and "lips" are spoken of as if they were trees bearing that fruit. In addition, "lips" represents people praising the Lord. AT: "praise that is an offering from those who acknowledge his name" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: praise that is the fruit of lips that acknowledge his name

contextId.information: The believers' souls, that is, the believers' spiritual well-being, are spoken of as if they were objects or animals that guards could keep watch over. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: keep watch over your souls
